body.header: What will I learn in this unit?
body.section:
Monologue (social context)You will listen to a talk about keeping healthy in winter.
Conversation (educational context)You will listen to two students talking about a presentation one of them is going to give about insects and human diseases.
Question typesYou will attempt four question types.Table completionShort answer questionsMatchingLabelling a diagram

section.p: These questions ask for specific information. You may be given incomplete notes or a table with spaces to fill using information from the listening text.
Read the instructions carefully. They will usually state that your answer should be NO MORE THAN THREE WORDS OR A NUMBER. But check this is the case.
Read through the notes or table and decide what you need to listen for. Take note of any headings. They will give you a good indication of what the text will be about.
You may be able to predict one or two of the answers.
Check whether the questions or spaces are arranged vertically or horizontally.
Complete the notes or table as you listen. The information will be given in the same order as the spaces in the notes or table.
Use the words you hear, not your own.
Remember as you write, the answer could be a number, one word, two words or three words but not four words or more.
If you think you need more than three words your answer is probably incorrect.
These are questions requiring general information or specific details which you will find by listening to the text. You will be given a question and a space for your answer.
Read the instructions carefully. They will usually state that your answer should be NO MORE THAN THREE WORDS. But check this is the case.
Read through all the questions.
Underline the key words in the questions.
Decide what kind of information you are listening for. Look out for question words like 'where' and 'who' which indicate you should listen out for specific things like places and people.
You may be able to predict one or two of the answers.
If you don't know the meaning of any of the words in the questions look at the other questions. They might have some associated vocabulary in them to help you guess the meaning.
Answer the questions as you listen.
The information will be given in the same order as the questions although it may be expressed differently.
You may use your own words.
Remember as you write, the answer could be one word, two words or three words but not four words or more.
If you think you need more than three words your answer is probably wrong.

You are usually given words or phrases to match to other words, phrases or sentences. You will usually have to insert a letter representing one of the words or phrases beside a number which represents another word or phrase.
Read the instructions carefully.
Read through all the words, phrases or sentences and underline key words.
Try to work out what you will be listening to.
You may be able to predict one or two of the answers.
Think about how any unusual names might be pronounced.
The information will be given in the same order as the numbered words or phrases.
Listen out for the words or phrases in the exercise.
Cross out the lettered words or phrases as you use them.
Be careful of words that either look or sound similar.
You will be given a diagram and asked to label it with labels given in the listening text. Sometimes you may be given a box of words or phrases from which to select the labels.
Read the instructions carefully. They will state how many words you should use if there is not a box of labels provided. You could be asked to write one word only.
Study the diagram.
You may be able to predict one or two answers or associated vocabulary that you may hear connected to a particular label.
Check whether the labels are numbered in a clockwise or anticlockwise direction.
The information will be given in the same order as the numbers on the diagram.
Write down or select the labels as you listen.
Use the words you hear, not your own.
Remember to listen carefully when words are spelt out. Write them down even if you don't know where they go.
Use the information given on the diagram to help you if you get lost.
